Award.AwardTitle: Tunable Continuous Wave THz Source Based on a Room Temperature Quantum Cascade Laser

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The objective of this program is to create a compact, efficient, and tunable continuous wave THz light source at room temperature. This will be accomplished by creating a monolithic, two-frequency, mid-infrared, tunable laser with a built-in nonlinearity. High power, tunable THz radiation will be emitted via difference frequency generation, and the packaging will be optimized for thermal management and collection of phase-matched THz output.
Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this project lies in developing the core technologies and integration processes necessary to produce a multi-functional monolithic THz emitter. The various research topics necessary include modeling of intersubband gain, nonlinearity, and transport , thermal management, laser cavity nonlinearities, and efficient free space coupling of THz radiation. Successful integration onto a common platform will play a transformative role in the further development of multi-functional mid-infrared and THz optoelectronic integrated circuits.
Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of this work will impact both scientific infrastructure and education. First, the small size of this source and potential for mass production may represent a future enabling technology for widespread access to the THz spectral region. This type of THz source has numerous applications in basic science, as well as in explosive and drug detection, security screening (T-ray imaging), astronomy/ astrophysics, and medical imaging. Progress in source development will be published and accessible to the general scientific community. Finally, aspects of the research will be used as classroom examples at Northwestern University and provide secondary research opportunities for undergraduates and local high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF project ‘Tunable Continuous Wave THz Source Based on a Room Temperature Quantum Cascade Laser’ (Federal Award ID: 1306397) addresses critical needs in the field of high-power continuous wave (CW), frequency agile THz laser source at room temperature. This type of THz source has numerous applications in basic sciences, as well as in THz spectroscopy, explosive and drug detection, security screening, astronomy, and medical diagnosis. With the support of this project, we create a revolutionary continuous wave monolithic tunable THz source working at room temperature which is compact (packaging size of 10x10x2 mm3), mass-producible, and has sub-mW power output at room temperature continuous wave operation with a wide frequency tuning range of 2.0-4.4 THz.

The core achievements of this project are: (1) Demonstrated world's first room temperature CW THz laser source from quantum cascade lasers (QCLs), and the highest THz power emission (~2 mW) at room temperature pulsed mode operation. (This work was also highlighted in Nature Photonics: 8, 585 (2014)). (2) Demonstrated the widest monolithic THz tuning from 2.6 to 4.2 THz at room temperature pulsed mode operation from a single THz emitter. (3) Demonstrated the highest THz continuous wave power of 14 μW and the first monolithic THz tuning from 2.06 to 4.35 THz at room temperature continuous wave operation. (This work was published in Nature Scientific Reports: 6, 23595 (2016)). Room temperature THz emitter is active area of investigation in the optoelectronic and physics communities. The accomplished results of this project aroused lots of interest to many people in these fields and received extensive scientific media reports, such as Laser Focus World, Photonics Spectra, Semiconductor Today, etc. In addition, the demonstrated THz source will be of interest to a much wider community of scientists, for a variety of spectroscopic, imaging, and medical applications.

Broader impacts: With this research, we systematically address many basic problems existing for previous THz sources by using an optimized highly efficient active region, a new sampled-grating frequency tuning design, and improved packaging technique for the multi-section device. The demonstrated THz device has a truly small size of 10x10x2 mm3 after packaging, operates at room temperature continuous wave operation, and is monolithic frequency tunable up to 2-4.5 THz. As such, it can be a drop-in replacement for existing THz sources in many spectroscopy applications. Also, with significant potential for mass production, the source can be made cheaply, similar to other semiconductor lasers. This will allow many more people access to THz sources for novel and unique research.

This NSF project also makes an excellent case study for how theory, technology, and experiment all play a role in developing a single integrated tunable THz laser source. As such, aspects of the device design and fabrication have been incorporated into the Solid State Engineering curriculum at Northwestern University as real-world examples. Graduate students and post-docs funded through this work were able to present this work to course attendees and at conferences. The involvement of undergraduates and high-school students (through mentorship) has been emphasized, by leveraging existing programs with a strong focus on under-represented minorities, to increase the effectiveness and scope of the program.
